newsitem.title: USA: IBM's Lotus to unveil Web site services.
newsitem.headline: IBM's Lotus to unveil Web site services.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp's Lotus Development Corp unit is expected to unveil Tuesday software that lets companies and individuals "rent" space on World Wide Web sites, to collaborate on documents.

Lotus, based in Cambridge, Mass., is expected to unveil software that runs on a new version of Lotus Notes code named Domino, which is designed entirely around Internet technology, analysts said. Notes is software for working in groups.
The software will be available on a rental basis directly from Internet service providers or Notes service providers, said analysts who asked not to be named.
The software will let individuals use a temporary Web site, designed for collaboration with Lotus's Domino software.
"If I am a services provider, like MCI (Communications Corp), I can create a collaborative Web site and rent it out to people," said one analyst who asked not to be named.

The technology could be used by individuals, small businesses, and others who do not want the hassel and cost of maitaining a Web site, but who wish to have a temporary site that stores documents that require input from others.
The analyst said that Lotus is working with seven different service providers. A Lotus spokesman was not available.
Lotus issued an advisory Friday saying it would host a teleconference to announce products that extend its Internet technology to a new set of users, including consumers.

"It has the potential to be extremely lucrative for Lotus," said one analyst. "There are a lot of companies who don't want to put in a large, collaborative structure, but they want to have access to this."

The service will be similar to its former deal with AT&T Corp, which sold Network Notes to big and small companies that did not want to install or maintain a corporate network, or to run and maintain Lotus Notes software on their networks.
